GRACEY.</br>Fath and trath, I believe, in ten parishes round,</br>Zuch a rouge, zuch a villain, es nat to be found.
MALLY.</br>Why, what's the fusing long wee then, un Gracey Chilvean.

GRACEY.</br>A fusing, a quatha add splet hes ould brain;</br>Why, our Martin's com'd hom chield, zo drunk as a beast,</br>Zo cross as the gallish, from Peran zand feast:</br>He com'd in a tottering, a cursing and zwearing,</br>Zo hard as a stump horse, a tarving and taring.
MALLY.</br>Never mind 'em, un Gracey, go futch 'en to bed,</br>He'll sleep all the lequor away from his head.

GRACEY.</br>Why, I wed'nt go nist em to git the King's crown,</br>For he zwears if I speak to en, he'll cleve ma skull down;</br>Thou never, in all thy borne days, fath and zure,</br>Ded'st behold such a mazegery pattick before;</br>Why, he scat all to madjans and jouds for the nones,</br>A clum bason of scald milk about on the stones;</br>And took't up a shoul to stave me outright,</br>But I run'd away, ready to fainty for fright:</br>Lord, tell me, un Mally, what shall I do by en,</br>For odds down derry's death, I'm afraid to go ny en.
MALLY.</br>I know what I'd do, if so be 'twas my case,</br>I'd scat the ould chacks ow 'en, I'd trem en, un Grace.

GRACEY.</br>I'm afeard of my life to go ny the ould vellan,</br>Else, please Father, I bleve I shud parfectly kill en.</br>I'll never no more be so bald and abus'd,</br>My arms are like basom the rouge have em bruis'd;</br>I made for his zupper, a raugetty pye,</br>But a shant clunk a crum ow' en, I wish I may dy.

MALLY.</br>I tould thee before the job was a done,</br>Thou wed'st com to repent it as zure as a gun;</br>But, thous't not hearken to me, not doubting for why,</br>Because thou knowst much better than I:</br>But I know'd the tricks ow' en, before thou hadst go en,</br>For I tould thee of maches, of stories about en,</br>But thou answers'd zo toit and shrink'd up thy nose,</br>As thinking 'twas great lashing lys, I suppose.</br>There's one of his pranks I shall always remember,</br>'Tis three years ago, com the eighth of November;</br>I'd two pretty young mabjers as eyes could behold,</br>Zo fat as the butter, just eighteen weeks ould,</br>They were out in the town-place, a picking for meat,</br>Zo I hove down some pellas among them to eat,</br>When who but your man com'd tottering along,</br>Zo drunk, fath, I thoft he'd ha fallen in the dung;</br>He left fale his hogan bag just by the door,</br>Zo I cal'd to the man, as one would be zure,</br>"Harkee, Martin, doust hier chield, take up thy bag,"</br>"Arrah," says he, "who's that calling my dog."</br>Zo he runn'd to the hadge, ded no better nor worse,</br>Nack'd the mabjers both stif, with a great moor of furze.</br>Like a' now, ef I had'nt gone out of his way,</br>He'd a done as he did by John Rouse, t' other day,</br>When he got in his tantrums, a wilful ould devil,</br>And flam'd the poor man o'er the head with a kebel.</br>Fath and soul, then, un Grace, ef so be he don't alter,</br>I believe in my consense, he'll dy in a halter.

GRACEY.</br>When the cyder es run'd away every drap,</br>'Tis to late of thinking of stoping the tap:</br>And marriage must go as God has ordain</br>But a parson wed zwear to be plagued zo chilvean:</br>Had I known the cause ow' en but nine weeks ago,</br>I'd never a had the ould vellan, I know;</br>But he wow'd and he zwore, ef I wed he hes wife,</br>I never sho'd want all the days of my life;</br>And he brought me a nackin and corn save from pren,</br>In my consense, thoft I, I shal live like a Queen.</br>But, 'tis plaguy provoking, add splet es ould head,</br>To be pooted and slap'd, zo I wish I was ded.</br>Why, he spent hase his wages last Saturday night,</br>Like enow, that by this time, tes gone every doit;</br>But, I'll tam the ould devil before it be long,</br>Ef I cant wethe my fist, I will weth my tongue.</br>
